question_text: A 40-year-old woman is evaluated for a pruritic rash that is limited to her palms and fingers.Skin findings are shown.
question_stem: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
critique: The most likely diagnosis is dyshidrotic eczema (Option A). Also known as pompholyx, dyshidrotic eczema typically presents as recurrent episodes of intense pruritus on the palms and/or soles. Physical findings include multiple small vesicles on the palmar or plantar skin, especially along the lateral aspects of the fingers and toes. The vesicles desquamate, leaving erosions and fissures. Dyshidrotic eczema usually lasts 3 to 4 weeks.
